00:09:07.525 --> 00:09:10.227
Just days before Terence died,

00:09:10.227 --> 00:09:12.245
his oncologist said,

00:09:12.245 --> 00:09:15.493
"Tell Terence that better days are just ahead."

00:09:15.493 --> 00:09:17.875
Days before he died.

00:09:17.875 --> 00:09:19.308
Yet Ira Byock,

00:09:19.308 --> 00:09:21.656
the director of palliative medicine at Dartmouth

00:09:21.656 --> 00:09:24.587
said, "You know, the best doctor in the world

00:09:24.587 --> 00:09:29.195
has never succeeded in making anyone immortal."

00:09:29.195 --> 00:09:35.701
So what the experts call "denial," I call "hope,"

00:09:35.701 --> 00:09:38.035
and I'd like to borrow a phrase

00:09:38.035 --> 00:09:41.256
from my friends in software design.

00:09:41.256 --> 00:09:44.818
You just redefine denial and hope,

00:09:44.818 --> 00:09:48.046
and it becomes a feature of being human.

00:09:48.046 --> 00:09:49.907
It's not a bug.

00:09:49.907 --> 00:09:52.233
It's a feature.

00:09:52.233 --> 00:09:55.327
(Laughter)

00:09:55.327 --> 00:09:59.021
So we need to think more constructively

00:09:59.021 --> 00:10:03.333
about this very common, very profound

00:10:03.333 --> 00:10:07.289
and very powerful human emotion.

00:10:07.289 --> 00:10:09.913
It's part of the human condition,

00:10:09.913 --> 00:10:12.090
and yet our system and our thinking

00:10:12.090 --> 00:10:15.259
isn't built to accommodate it.

00:10:15.259 --> 00:10:18.314
So Terence told me a story on that long-ago night,

00:10:18.314 --> 00:10:20.219
and I believed it.

00:10:20.219 --> 00:10:23.333
Maybe I wanted to believe it.

00:10:23.333 --> 00:10:28.662
And during Terence's illness, I, we,

00:10:28.662 --> 00:10:30.384
we wanted to believe the story

00:10:30.384 --> 00:10:32.979
of our fight together too.

00:10:32.979 --> 00:10:36.715
Giving up the fight -- for that's how it felt,

00:10:36.715 --> 00:10:38.654
it felt like giving up --

00:10:38.654 --> 00:10:41.371
meant giving up not only his life

00:10:41.371 --> 00:10:45.078
but also our story,

00:10:45.078 --> 00:10:47.288
our story of us as fighters,

00:10:47.288 --> 00:10:50.218
the story of us as invincible,

00:10:50.218 --> 00:10:52.426
and for the doctors, the story of themselves

00:10:52.426 --> 00:10:54.984
as healers.

00:10:54.984 --> 00:10:57.668
So what do we need?

00:10:57.668 --> 00:11:00.607
Maybe we don't need a new piece of paper.

00:11:00.607 --> 00:11:03.554
Maybe we need a new story,

00:11:03.554 --> 00:11:07.563
not a story about giving up the fight

00:11:07.563 --> 00:11:09.834
or of hopelessness,

00:11:09.834 --> 00:11:13.245
but rather a story of victory and triumph,

00:11:13.245 --> 00:11:18.088
of a valiant battle and, eventually,

00:11:18.088 --> 00:11:20.408
a graceful retreat,

00:11:20.408 --> 00:11:23.415
a story that acknowledges

00:11:23.415 --> 00:11:27.178
that not even the greatest general defeats every foe,

00:11:27.178 --> 00:11:29.799
that no doctor has ever succeeded

00:11:29.799 --> 00:11:32.189
in making anyone immortal,

00:11:32.189 --> 00:11:38.255
and that no wife, no matter how hard she tried,

00:11:38.255 --> 00:11:42.940
has ever stopped even the bravest,

00:11:42.940 --> 00:11:46.989
wittiest and most maddeningly lovable husband

00:11:46.989 --> 00:11:51.182
from dying when it was his time to go.

00:11:51.182 --> 00:11:53.495
People did mention hospice,

00:11:53.495 --> 00:11:56.866
but I wouldn't listen.

00:11:56.866 --> 00:12:00.791
Hospice was for people who were dying,

00:12:00.791 --> 00:12:03.564
and Terence wasn't dying.

00:12:03.564 --> 00:12:06.474
As a result, he spent just four days in hospice,

00:12:06.474 --> 00:12:08.291
which I'm sure, as you all know,

00:12:08.291 --> 00:12:10.381
is a pretty typical outcome,

00:12:10.381 --> 00:12:11.893
and we never said goodbye

00:12:11.893 --> 00:12:14.948
because we were unprepared for the end.

00:12:14.948 --> 00:12:18.695
We have a noble path to curing the disease,

00:12:18.695 --> 00:12:21.025
patients and doctors alike,

00:12:21.025 --> 00:12:23.148
but there doesn't seem to be

00:12:23.148 --> 00:12:25.748
a noble path to dying.

00:12:25.748 --> 00:12:28.806
Dying is seen as failing,

00:12:28.806 --> 00:12:31.458
and we had a heroic narrative

00:12:31.458 --> 00:12:33.551
for fighting together,

00:12:33.551 --> 00:12:38.581
but we didn't have a heroic narrative for letting go.

00:12:38.581 --> 00:12:42.699
So maybe we need a narrative

00:12:42.699 --> 00:12:46.175
for acknowledging the end, and for saying goodbye,

00:12:46.175 --> 00:12:48.737
and maybe our new story will be

00:12:48.737 --> 00:12:53.343
about a hero's fight, and a hero's goodbye.

00:12:53.343 --> 00:12:55.810
Terence loved poetry,

00:12:55.810 --> 00:12:59.037
and the Greek poet Constantine Cavafy

00:12:59.037 --> 00:13:01.466
is one of my favorite poets.

00:13:01.466 --> 00:13:04.350
So I'll give you a couple lines from him.

00:13:04.350 --> 00:13:06.566
This is a poem about Mark Antony.

00:13:06.566 --> 00:13:09.259
You know Mark Antony, the conquering hero,

00:13:09.259 --> 00:13:11.124
Cleopatra's guy?

00:13:11.124 --> 00:13:13.661
Actually, one of Cleopatra's guys.

00:13:13.661 --> 00:13:16.086
And he's been a pretty good general.

00:13:16.086 --> 00:13:17.146
He's won all the fights,

00:13:17.146 --> 00:13:19.601
he's eluded all the people that are out to get him,

00:13:19.601 --> 00:13:21.389
and yet this time, finally,

00:13:21.389 --> 00:13:23.138
he's come to the city of Alexandria

00:13:23.138 --> 00:13:24.820
and realized he's lost.

00:13:24.820 --> 00:13:26.536
The people are leaving. They're playing instruments.

00:13:26.536 --> 00:13:27.859
They're singing.

00:13:27.859 --> 00:13:30.459
And suddenly he knows he's been defeated.

00:13:30.459 --> 00:13:32.638
And he suddenly knows

00:13:32.638 --> 00:13:35.163
he's been deserted by the gods,

00:13:35.163 --> 00:13:37.103
and it's time to let go.

00:13:37.103 --> 00:13:39.070
And the poet tells him what to do.

00:13:39.070 --> 00:13:42.336
He tells him how to say a noble goodbye,

00:13:42.336 --> 00:13:46.183
a goodbye that's fit for a hero.

00:13:46.183 --> 00:13:48.932
"As if long-prepared,

00:13:48.932 --> 00:13:51.611
as if courageous,

00:13:51.611 --> 00:13:54.208
as it becomes you

00:13:54.208 --> 00:13:56.380
who were worthy of such a city,

00:13:56.380 --> 00:13:58.783
approach the window with a firm step,

00:13:58.783 --> 00:14:01.318
and with emotion,

00:14:01.318 --> 00:14:03.517
but not with the entreaties

00:14:03.517 --> 00:14:06.278
or the complaints of a coward,

00:14:06.278 --> 00:14:08.249
as a last enjoyment,

00:14:08.249 --> 00:14:10.373
listen to the sounds,

00:14:10.373 --> 00:14:13.707
the exquisite instruments of the musical troops,

00:14:13.707 --> 00:14:15.988
and bid her farewell,

00:14:15.988 --> 00:14:20.403
the Alexandria you are losing."

00:14:20.403 --> 00:14:24.093
That's a goodbye for a man who was larger than life,

00:14:24.093 --> 00:14:26.111
a goodbye for a man

00:14:26.111 --> 00:14:28.085
for whom anything,

00:14:28.085 --> 00:14:31.193
well, almost anything,

00:14:31.193 --> 00:14:33.083
was possible,

00:14:33.083 --> 00:14:36.223
a goodbye for a man who kept hope alive.

00:14:36.223 --> 00:14:38.416
And isn't that what we're missing?

00:14:38.416 --> 00:14:40.475
How can we learn that people's decisions

00:14:40.475 --> 00:14:41.985
about their loved ones

00:14:41.985 --> 00:14:45.914
are often based strongly, powerfully,

00:14:45.914 --> 00:14:48.766
many times irrationally,

00:14:48.766 --> 00:14:51.110
on the slimmest of hopes?

00:14:51.110 --> 00:14:54.132
The overwhelming presence of hope

00:14:54.132 --> 00:14:55.555
isn't denial.

00:14:55.555 --> 00:14:58.375
It's part of our DNA as humans,

00:14:58.375 --> 00:15:00.693
and maybe it's time our healthcare system --

00:15:00.693 --> 00:15:05.177
doctors, patients, insurance companies, us,

00:15:05.177 --> 00:15:09.151
started accounting for the power of that hope.

00:15:09.151 --> 00:15:11.451
Hope isn't a bug.

00:15:11.451 --> 00:15:13.820
It's a feature.

00:15:13.820 --> 00:15:16.315
Thank you.

00:15:16.315 --> 00:15:19.370
(Applause)

title: Ingenious homes in unexpected places
transcript: Throughout my career, I've been fortunate enough to work with many of the great international architects, documenting their work and observing how their designs have the capacity to influence the cities in which they sit. I think of new cities like Dubai or ancient cities like Rome with Zaha Hadid's incredible MAXXI museum, or like right here in New York with the High Line, a city which has been so much influenced by the development of this.But what I find really fascinating is what happens when architects and planners leave and these places become appropriated by people, like here in Chandigarh, India, the city which has been completely designed by the architect Le Corbusier. Now 60 years later, the city has been taken over by people in very different ways from whatever perhaps intended for, like here, where you have the people sitting in the windows of the assembly hall. But over the course of several years, I've been documenting Rem Koolhaas's CCTV building in Beijing and the olympic stadium in the same city by the architects Herzog and de Meuron. At these large-scale construction sites in China, you see a sort of makeshift camp where workers live during the entire building process. As the length of the construction takes years, workers end up forming a rather rough-and-ready informal city, making for quite a juxtaposition against the sophisticated structures that they're building.Over the past seven years, I've been following my fascination with the built environment, and for those of you who know me, you would say that this obsession has led me to live out of a suitcase 365 days a year. Being constantly on the move means that sometimes I am able to catch life's most unpredictable moments, like here in New York the day after the Sandy storm hit the city.Just over three years ago, I was for the first time in Caracas, Venezuela, and while flying over the city, I was just amazed by the extent to which the slums reach into every corner of the city, a place where nearly 70 percent of the population lives in slums, draped literally all over the mountains. During a conversation with local architects Urban-Think Tank, I learned about the Torre David, a 45-story office building which sits right in the center of Caracas. The building was under construction until the collapse of the Venezuelan economy and the death of the developer in the early '90s. About eight years ago, people started moving into the abandoned tower and began to build their homes right in between every column of this unfinished tower. There's only one little entrance to the entire building, and the 3,000 residents come in and out through that single door. Together, the inhabitants created public spaces and designed them to feel more like a home and less like an unfinished tower. In the lobby, they painted the walls and planted trees. They also made a basketball court. But when you look up closely, you see massive holes where elevators and services would have run through.Within the tower, people have come up with all sorts of solutions in response to the various needs which arise from living in an unfinished tower. With no elevators, the tower is like a 45-story walkup. Designed in very specific ways by this group of people who haven't had any education in architecture or design. And with each inhabitant finding their own unique way of coming by, this tower becomes like a living city, a place which is alive with micro-economies and small businesses. The inventive inhabitants, for instance, find opportunities in the most unexpected cases, like the adjacent parking garage, which has been reclaimed as a taxi route to shuttle the inhabitants up through the ramps in order to shorten the hike up to the apartments.A walk through the tower reveals how residents have figured out how to create walls, how to make an air flow, how to create transparency, circulation throughout the tower, essentially creating a home that's completely adapted to the conditions of the site. When a new inhabitant moves into the tower, they already have a roof over their head, so they just typically mark their space with a few curtains or sheets. Slowly, from found materials, walls rise, and people create a space out of any found objects or materials.It's remarkable to see the design decisions that they're making, like when everything is made out of red bricks, some residents will cover that red brick with another layer of red brick-patterned wallpaper just to make it a kind of clean finish.The inhabitants literally built up these homes with their own hands, and this labor of love instills a great sense of pride in many families living in this tower. They typically make the best out of their conditions, and try to make their spaces look nice and homey, or at least up until as far as they can reach. Throughout the tower, you come across all kinds of services, like the barber, small factories, and every floor has a little grocery store or shop. And you even find a church. And on the 30th floor, there is a gym where all the weights and barbells are made out of the leftover pulleys from the elevators which were never installed. From the outside, behind this always-changing facade, you see how the fixed concrete beams provide a framework for the inhabitants to create their homes in an organic, intuitive way that responds directly to their needs.Let's go now to Africa, to Nigeria, to a community called Makoko, a slum where 150,000 people live just meters above the Lagos Lagoon. While it may appear to be a completely chaotic place, when you see it from above, there seems to be a whole grid of waterways and canals connecting each and every home. From the main dock, people board long wooden canoes which carry them out to their various homes and shops located in the expansive area. When out on the water, it's clear that life has been completely adapted to this very specific way of living. Even the canoes become variety stores where ladies paddle from house to house, selling anything from toothpaste to fresh fruits. Behind every window and door frame, you'll see a small child peering back at you, and while Makoko seems to be packed with people, what's more shocking is actually the amount of children pouring out of every building. The population growth in Nigeria, and especially in these areas like Makoko, are painful reminders of how out of control things really are.In Makoko, very few systems and infrastructures exist. Electricity is rigged and freshest water comes from self-built wells throughout the area. This entire economic model is designed to meet a specific way of living on the water, so fishing and boat-making are common professions. You'll have a set of entrepreneurs who have set up businesses throughout the area, like barbershops, CD and DVD stores, movie theaters, tailors, everything is there. There is even a photo studio where you see the sort of aspiration to live in a real house or to be associated with a faraway place, like that hotel in Sweden.On this particular evening, I came across this live band dressed to the T in their coordinating outfits. They were floating through the canals in a large canoe with a fitted-out generator for all of the community to enjoy.By nightfall, the area becomes almost pitch black, save for a small lightbulb or a fire.What originally brought me to Makoko was this project from a friend of mine, Kunlé Adeyemi, who recently finished building this three-story floating school for the kids in Makoko. With this entire village existing on the water, public space is very limited, so now that the school is finished, the ground floor is a playground for the kids, but when classes are out, the platform is just like a town square, where the fishermen mend their nets and floating shopkeepers dock their boats.Another place I'd like to share with you is the Zabbaleen in Cairo. They're descendants of farmers who began migrating from the upper Egypt in the '40s, and today they make their living by collecting and recycling waste from homes from all over Cairo. For years, the Zabbaleen would live in makeshift villages where they would move around trying to avoid the local authorities, but in the early 1980s, they settled on the Mokattam rocks just at the eastern edge of the city. Today, they live in this area, approximately 50,000 to 70,000 people, who live in this community of self-built multi-story houses where up to three generations live in one structure. While these apartments that they built for themselves appear to lack any planning or formal grid, each family specializing in a certain form of recycling means that the ground floor of each apartment is reserved for garbage-related activities and the upper floor is dedicated to living space. I find it incredible to see how these piles and piles of garbage are invisible to the people who live there, like this very distinguished man who is posing while all this garbage is sort of streaming out behind him, or like these two young men who are sitting and chatting amongst these tons of garbage. While to most of us, living amongst these piles and piles of garbage may seem totally uninhabitable, to those in the Zabbaleen, this is just a different type of normal. In all these places I've talked about today, what I do find fascinating is that there's really no such thing as normal, and it proves that people are able to adapt to any kind of situation. Throughout the day, it's quite common to come across a small party taking place in the streets, just like this engagement party. In this tradition, the bride-to-be displays all of their belongings, which they soon bring to their new husband. A gathering like this one offers such a juxtaposition where all the new stuff is displayed and all the garbage is used as props to display all their new home accessories. Like Makoko and the Torre David, throughout the Zabbaleen you'll find all the same facilities as in any typical neighborhood. There are the retail shops, the cafes and the restaurants, and the community is this community of Coptic Christians, so you'll also find a church, along with the scores of religious iconographies throughout the area, and also all the everyday services like the electronic repair shops, the barbers, everything.Visiting the homes of the Zabbaleen is also full of surprises. While from the outside, these homes look like any other informal structure in the city, when you step inside, you are met with all manner of design decisions and interior decoration. Despite having limited access to space and money, the homes in the area are designed with care and detail. Every apartment is unique, and this individuality tells a story about each family's circumstances and values. Many of these people take their homes and interior spaces very seriously, putting a lot of work and care into the details. The shared spaces are also treated in the same manner, where walls are decorated in faux marble patterns.But despite this elaborate decor, sometimes these apartments are used in very unexpected ways, like this home which caught my attention while all the mud and the grass was literally seeping out under the front door. When I was let in, it appeared that this fifth-floor apartment was being transformed into a complete animal farm, where six or seven cows stood grazing in what otherwise would be the living room. But then in the apartment across the hall from this cow shed lives a newly married couple in what locals describe as one of the nicest apartments in the area.The attention to this detail astonished me, and as the owner of the home so proudly led me around this apartment, from floor to ceiling, every part was decorated. But if it weren't for the strangely familiar stomach-churning odor that constantly passes through the apartment, it would be easy to forget that you are standing next to a cow shed and on top of a landfill. What moved me the most was that despite these seemingly inhospitable conditions, I was welcomed with open arms into a home that was made with love, care, and unreserved passion.Let's move across the map to China, to an area called Shanxi, Henan and Gansu. In a region famous for the soft, porous Loess Plateau soil, there lived until recently an estimated 40 million people in these houses underground. These dwellings are called the yaodongs. Through this architecture by subtraction, these yaodongs are built literally inside of the soil. In these villages, you see an entirely altered landscape, and hidden behind these mounds of dirt are these square, rectangular houses which sit seven meters below the ground. When I asked people why they were digging their houses from the ground, they simply replied that they are poor wheat and apple farmers who didn't have the money to buy materials, and this digging out was their most logical form of living.From Makoko to Zabbaleen, these communities have approached the tasks of planning, design and management of their communities and neighborhoods in ways that respond specifically to their environment and circumstances. Created by these very people who live, work and play in these particular spaces, these neighborhoods are intuitively designed to make the most of their circumstances. In most of these places, the government is completely absent, leaving inhabitants with no choice but to reappropriate found materials, and while these communities are highly disadvantaged, they do present examples of brilliant forms of ingenuity, and prove that indeed we have the ability to adapt to all manner of circumstances. What makes places like the Torre David particularly remarkable is this sort of skeleton framework where people can have a foundation where they can tap into. Now imagine what these already ingenious communities could create themselves, and how highly particular their solutions would be, if they were given the basic infrastructures that they could tap into.Today, you see these large residential development projects which offer cookie-cutter housing solutions to massive amounts of people. From China to Brazil, these projects attempt to provide as many houses as possible, but they're completely generic and simply do not work as an answer to the individual needs of the people.I would like to end with a quote from a friend of mine and a source of inspiration, Zita Cobb, the founder of the wonderful Shorefast Foundation, based out of Fogo Island, Newfoundland. She says that "there's this plague of sameness which is killing the human joy," and I couldn't agree with her more.Thank you.(Applause)

00:02:33.735 --> 00:02:36.088
I learned about the Torre David,

00:02:36.088 --> 00:02:38.631
a 45-story office building which sits

00:02:38.631 --> 00:02:40.684
right in the center of Caracas.

00:02:40.684 --> 00:02:42.287
The building was under construction

00:02:42.287 --> 00:02:44.813
until the collapse of the Venezuelan economy

00:02:44.813 --> 00:02:48.179
and the death of the developer in the early '90s.

00:02:48.179 --> 00:02:51.141
About eight years ago, people started moving

00:02:51.141 --> 00:02:53.154
into the abandoned tower

00:02:53.154 --> 00:02:55.173
and began to build their homes right in between

00:02:55.173 --> 00:02:58.372
every column of this unfinished tower.

00:02:58.372 --> 00:03:01.169
There's only one little entrance to the entire building,

00:03:01.169 --> 00:03:04.107
and the 3,000 residents come in and out

00:03:04.107 --> 00:03:06.175
through that single door.

00:03:06.175 --> 00:03:09.064
Together, the inhabitants created public spaces

00:03:09.064 --> 00:03:11.337
and designed them to feel more like a home

00:03:11.337 --> 00:03:13.932
and less like an unfinished tower.

00:03:13.932 --> 00:03:17.447
In the lobby, they painted the walls and planted trees.

00:03:17.447 --> 00:03:20.457
They also made a basketball court.

00:03:20.457 --> 00:03:22.157
But when you look up closely,

00:03:22.157 --> 00:03:24.638
you see massive holes where elevators

00:03:24.638 --> 00:03:27.218
and services would have run through.

00:03:27.218 --> 00:03:29.207
Within the tower, people have come up

00:03:29.207 --> 00:03:31.473
with all sorts of solutions

00:03:31.473 --> 00:03:33.454
in response to the various needs

00:03:33.454 --> 00:03:36.941
which arise from living in an unfinished tower.

00:03:36.941 --> 00:03:38.140
With no elevators,

00:03:38.140 --> 00:03:41.468
the tower is like a 45-story walkup.

00:03:41.468 --> 00:03:43.718
Designed in very specific ways

00:03:43.718 --> 00:03:45.194
by this group of people

00:03:45.194 --> 00:03:49.090
who haven't had any education in architecture or design.

00:03:49.090 --> 00:03:51.371
And with each inhabitant finding their own

00:03:51.371 --> 00:03:53.338
unique way of coming by,

00:03:53.338 --> 00:03:56.140
this tower becomes like a living city,

00:03:56.140 --> 00:03:59.352
a place which is alive with micro-economies

00:03:59.352 --> 00:04:01.269
and small businesses.

00:04:01.269 --> 00:04:03.883
The inventive inhabitants, for instance,

00:04:03.883 --> 00:04:06.614
find opportunities in the most unexpected cases,

00:04:06.614 --> 00:04:08.739
like the adjacent parking garage,

00:04:08.739 --> 00:04:10.816
which has been reclaimed as a taxi route

00:04:10.816 --> 00:04:13.114
to shuttle the inhabitants up through the ramps

00:04:13.114 --> 00:04:14.561
in order to shorten the hike

00:04:14.561 --> 00:04:18.579
up to the apartments.

00:04:18.579 --> 00:04:20.489
A walk through the tower

00:04:20.489 --> 00:04:22.599
reveals how residents have figured out

00:04:22.599 --> 00:04:26.125
how to create walls, how to make an air flow,

00:04:26.125 --> 00:04:28.088
how to create transparency,

00:04:28.088 --> 00:04:30.512
circulation throughout the tower,

00:04:30.512 --> 00:04:32.331
essentially creating a home

00:04:32.331 --> 00:04:33.979
that's completely adapted

00:04:33.979 --> 00:04:37.257
to the conditions of the site.

00:04:37.257 --> 00:04:39.382
When a new inhabitant moves into the tower,

00:04:39.382 --> 00:04:41.290
they already have a roof over their head,

00:04:41.290 --> 00:04:43.329
so they just typically mark their space

00:04:43.329 --> 00:04:46.245
with a few curtains or sheets.

00:04:46.245 --> 00:04:49.417
Slowly, from found materials, walls rise,

00:04:49.417 --> 00:04:52.340
and people create a space out of any found objects

00:04:52.340 --> 00:04:54.229
or materials.

00:04:54.229 --> 00:04:56.729
It's remarkable to see the design decisions

00:04:56.729 --> 00:04:58.405
that they're making,

00:04:58.405 --> 00:05:01.040
like when everything is made out of red bricks,

00:05:01.040 --> 00:05:03.305
some residents will cover that red brick

00:05:03.305 --> 00:05:07.166
with another layer of red brick-patterned wallpaper

00:05:07.166 --> 00:05:12.218
just to make it a kind of clean finish.

00:05:12.218 --> 00:05:14.677
The inhabitants literally built up these homes

00:05:14.677 --> 00:05:16.834
with their own hands, and this labor of love

00:05:16.834 --> 00:05:18.587
instills a great sense of pride

00:05:18.587 --> 00:05:21.839
in many families living in this tower.

00:05:21.839 --> 00:05:24.773
They typically make the best out of their conditions,

00:05:24.773 --> 00:05:27.581
and try to make their spaces look nice and homey,

00:05:27.581 --> 00:05:31.128
or at least up until as far as they can reach.

00:05:31.128 --> 00:05:34.140
Throughout the tower, you come across

00:05:34.140 --> 00:05:36.306
all kinds of services, like the barber,

00:05:36.306 --> 00:05:40.119
small factories, and every floor has

00:05:40.119 --> 00:05:43.543
a little grocery store or shop.

00:05:43.543 --> 00:05:46.053
And you even find a church.

00:05:46.053 --> 00:05:48.417
And on the 30th floor, there is a gym

00:05:48.417 --> 00:05:50.171
where all the weights and barbells

00:05:50.171 --> 00:05:51.967
are made out of the leftover pulleys

00:05:51.967 --> 00:05:55.377
from the elevators which were never installed.

00:05:55.377 --> 00:05:58.012
From the outside, behind this always-changing facade,

00:05:58.012 --> 00:05:59.631
you see how the fixed concrete beams

00:05:59.631 --> 00:06:01.496
provide a framework for the inhabitants

00:06:01.496 --> 00:06:02.963
to create their homes

00:06:02.963 --> 00:06:04.839
in an organic, intuitive way

00:06:04.839 --> 00:06:07.556
that responds directly to their needs.

00:06:07.556 --> 00:06:10.211
Let's go now to Africa, to Nigeria,

00:06:10.211 --> 00:06:12.782
to a community called Makoko,

00:06:12.782 --> 00:06:15.341
a slum where 150,000 people

00:06:15.341 --> 00:06:18.523
live just meters above the Lagos Lagoon.

00:06:18.523 --> 00:06:22.237
While it may appear to be a completely chaotic place,

00:06:22.237 --> 00:06:24.643
when you see it from above, there seems to be

00:06:24.643 --> 00:06:27.808
a whole grid of waterways and canals

00:06:27.808 --> 00:06:30.322
connecting each and every home.

00:06:30.322 --> 00:06:34.536
From the main dock, people board long wooden canoes

00:06:34.536 --> 00:06:37.206
which carry them out to their various homes and shops

00:06:37.206 --> 00:06:39.881
located in the expansive area.

00:06:39.881 --> 00:06:41.828
When out on the water, it's clear

00:06:41.828 --> 00:06:43.717
that life has been completely adapted

00:06:43.717 --> 00:06:46.356
to this very specific way of living.

00:06:46.356 --> 00:06:49.003
Even the canoes become variety stores

00:06:49.003 --> 00:06:50.943
where ladies paddle from house to house,

00:06:50.943 --> 00:06:55.059
selling anything from toothpaste to fresh fruits.

00:06:55.059 --> 00:06:57.078
Behind every window and door frame,

00:06:57.078 --> 00:06:59.781
you'll see a small child peering back at you,

00:06:59.781 --> 00:07:02.765
and while Makoko seems to be packed with people,

00:07:02.765 --> 00:07:04.600
what's more shocking is actually

00:07:04.600 --> 00:07:08.085
the amount of children pouring out of every building.

00:07:08.085 --> 00:07:10.065
The population growth in Nigeria,

00:07:10.065 --> 00:07:12.534
and especially in these areas like Makoko,

00:07:12.534 --> 00:07:14.686
are painful reminders

00:07:14.686 --> 00:07:18.925
of how out of control things really are.

00:07:18.925 --> 00:07:21.204
In Makoko, very few systems

00:07:21.204 --> 00:07:23.070
and infrastructures exist.

00:07:23.070 --> 00:07:26.002
Electricity is rigged and freshest water

00:07:26.002 --> 00:07:29.367
comes from self-built wells throughout the area.

00:07:29.367 --> 00:07:31.771
This entire economic model

00:07:31.771 --> 00:07:34.563
is designed to meet a specific way of living

00:07:34.563 --> 00:07:37.678
on the water, so fishing and boat-making

00:07:37.678 --> 00:07:39.453
are common professions.

00:07:39.453 --> 00:07:41.420
You'll have a set of entrepreneurs

00:07:41.420 --> 00:07:44.444
who have set up businesses throughout the area,

00:07:44.444 --> 00:07:49.244
like barbershops, CD and DVD stores,

00:07:49.244 --> 00:07:54.607
movie theaters, tailors, everything is there.

00:07:54.607 --> 00:07:56.402
There is even a photo studio

00:07:56.402 --> 00:07:58.159
where you see the sort of aspiration

00:07:58.159 --> 00:08:01.459
to live in a real house or to be associated

00:08:01.459 --> 00:08:05.758
with a faraway place, like that hotel in Sweden.

00:08:05.758 --> 00:08:07.382
On this particular evening,

00:08:07.382 --> 00:08:09.486
I came across this live band

00:08:09.486 --> 00:08:12.637
dressed to the T in their coordinating outfits.

00:08:12.637 --> 00:08:14.667
They were floating through the canals

00:08:14.667 --> 00:08:17.591
in a large canoe with a fitted-out generator

00:08:17.591 --> 00:08:21.927
for all of the community to enjoy.

00:08:21.927 --> 00:08:24.918
By nightfall, the area becomes almost pitch black,

00:08:24.918 --> 00:08:26.746
save for a small lightbulb

00:08:26.746 --> 00:08:29.480
or a fire.

00:08:29.480 --> 00:08:32.095
What originally brought me to Makoko

00:08:32.095 --> 00:08:33.902
was this project from a friend of mine,

00:08:33.902 --> 00:08:36.703
Kunlé Adeyemi, who recently finished building

00:08:36.703 --> 00:08:38.749
this three-story floating school

00:08:38.749 --> 00:08:40.770
for the kids in Makoko.

00:08:40.770 --> 00:08:43.799
With this entire village existing on the water,

00:08:43.799 --> 00:08:46.222
public space is very limited,

00:08:46.222 --> 00:08:47.886
so now that the school is finished,

00:08:47.886 --> 00:08:51.260
the ground floor is a playground for the kids,

00:08:51.260 --> 00:08:53.127
but when classes are out, the platform

00:08:53.127 --> 00:08:54.698
is just like a town square,

00:08:54.698 --> 00:08:57.093
where the fishermen mend their nets

00:08:57.093 --> 00:09:01.258
and floating shopkeepers dock their boats.

00:09:01.258 --> 00:09:03.788
Another place I'd like to share with you

00:09:03.788 --> 00:09:05.836
is the Zabbaleen in Cairo.

00:09:05.836 --> 00:09:08.595
They're descendants of farmers who began migrating

00:09:08.595 --> 00:09:11.065
from the upper Egypt in the '40s,

00:09:11.065 --> 00:09:12.491
and today they make their living

00:09:12.491 --> 00:09:15.681
by collecting and recycling waste from homes

00:09:15.681 --> 00:09:17.932
from all over Cairo.

00:09:17.932 --> 00:09:21.054
For years, the Zabbaleen would live in makeshift villages

00:09:21.054 --> 00:09:22.723
where they would move around

00:09:22.723 --> 00:09:25.242
trying to avoid the local authorities,

00:09:25.242 --> 00:09:27.561
but in the early 1980s, they settled

00:09:27.561 --> 00:09:29.278
on the Mokattam rocks

00:09:29.278 --> 00:09:31.927
just at the eastern edge of the city.

00:09:31.927 --> 00:09:33.958
Today, they live in this area,

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:36.762
approximately 50,000 to 70,000 people,

00:09:36.762 --> 00:09:38.895
who live in this community of self-built

00:09:38.895 --> 00:09:41.075
multi-story houses

00:09:41.075 --> 00:09:45.368
where up to three generations live in one structure.

00:09:45.368 --> 00:09:47.846
While these apartments that they built for themselves

00:09:47.846 --> 00:09:50.831
appear to lack any planning or formal grid,

00:09:50.831 --> 00:09:54.237
each family specializing in a certain form of recycling

00:09:54.237 --> 00:09:56.470
means that the ground floor of each apartment

00:09:56.470 --> 00:10:00.127
is reserved for garbage-related activities

00:10:00.127 --> 00:10:04.150
and the upper floor is dedicated to living space.

00:10:04.150 --> 00:10:06.021
I find it incredible to see

00:10:06.021 --> 00:10:07.957
how these piles and piles of garbage

00:10:07.957 --> 00:10:10.468
are invisible to the people who live there,

00:10:10.468 --> 00:10:13.868
like this very distinguished man who is posing

00:10:13.868 --> 00:10:18.077
while all this garbage is sort of streaming out behind him,

00:10:18.077 --> 00:10:20.717
or like these two young men who are sitting

00:10:20.717 --> 00:10:25.569
and chatting amongst these tons of garbage.

00:10:25.569 --> 00:10:27.302
While to most of us, living amongst

00:10:27.302 --> 00:10:29.390
these piles and piles of garbage

00:10:29.390 --> 00:10:31.741
may seem totally uninhabitable,

00:10:31.741 --> 00:10:33.831
to those in the Zabbaleen, this is just

00:10:33.831 --> 00:10:36.310
a different type of normal.

00:10:36.310 --> 00:10:38.947
In all these places I've talked about today,

00:10:38.947 --> 00:10:41.068
what I do find fascinating is that there's really

00:10:41.068 --> 00:10:42.666
no such thing as normal,

00:10:42.666 --> 00:10:44.871
and it proves that people are able to adapt

00:10:44.871 --> 00:10:47.246
to any kind of situation.

00:10:47.246 --> 00:10:48.762
Throughout the day, it's quite common

00:10:48.762 --> 00:10:52.110
to come across a small party taking place

00:10:52.110 --> 00:10:55.954
in the streets, just like this engagement party.

00:10:55.954 --> 00:10:57.941
In this tradition, the bride-to-be

00:10:57.941 --> 00:11:00.086
displays all of their belongings,

00:11:00.086 --> 00:11:02.280
which they soon bring to their new husband.

00:11:02.280 --> 00:11:04.311
A gathering like this one

00:11:04.311 --> 00:11:06.208
offers such a juxtaposition

00:11:06.208 --> 00:11:08.986
where all the new stuff is displayed

00:11:08.986 --> 00:11:11.352
and all the garbage is used

00:11:11.352 --> 00:11:17.989
as props to display all their new home accessories.

00:11:17.989 --> 00:11:20.155
Like Makoko and the Torre David,

00:11:20.155 --> 00:11:21.700
throughout the Zabbaleen you'll find all

00:11:21.700 --> 00:11:24.844
the same facilities as in any typical neighborhood.

00:11:24.844 --> 00:11:26.924
There are the retail shops, the cafes

00:11:26.924 --> 00:11:29.244
and the restaurants, and the community

00:11:29.244 --> 00:11:32.185
is this community of Coptic Christians,

00:11:32.185 --> 00:11:34.424
so you'll also find a church,

00:11:34.424 --> 00:11:37.869
along with the scores of religious iconographies

00:11:37.869 --> 00:11:39.627
throughout the area,

00:11:39.627 --> 00:11:42.816
and also all the everyday services

00:11:42.816 --> 00:11:44.615
like the electronic repair shops,

00:11:44.615 --> 00:11:47.703
the barbers, everything.

00:11:47.703 --> 00:11:49.876
Visiting the homes of the Zabbaleen

00:11:49.876 --> 00:11:51.565
is also full of surprises.

00:11:51.565 --> 00:11:53.077
While from the outside,

00:11:53.077 --> 00:11:55.620
these homes look like any other informal structure

00:11:55.620 --> 00:11:57.938
in the city, when you step inside,

00:11:57.938 --> 00:12:01.801
you are met with all manner of design decisions

00:12:01.801 --> 00:12:04.068
and interior decoration.

00:12:04.068 --> 00:12:07.232
Despite having limited access to space and money,

00:12:07.232 --> 00:12:09.111
the homes in the area are designed

00:12:09.111 --> 00:12:11.097
with care and detail.

00:12:11.097 --> 00:12:13.140
Every apartment is unique,

00:12:13.140 --> 00:12:14.933
and this individuality tells a story

00:12:14.933 --> 00:12:18.059
about each family's circumstances and values.

00:12:18.059 --> 00:12:20.205
Many of these people take their homes

00:12:20.205 --> 00:12:23.373
and interior spaces very seriously,

00:12:23.373 --> 00:12:24.880
putting a lot of work and care

00:12:24.880 --> 00:12:26.206
into the details.

00:12:26.206 --> 00:12:29.379
The shared spaces are also treated in the same manner,

00:12:29.379 --> 00:12:33.236
where walls are decorated in faux marble patterns.

00:12:33.236 --> 00:12:36.219
But despite this elaborate decor,

00:12:36.219 --> 00:12:38.773
sometimes these apartments are used

00:12:38.773 --> 00:12:40.583
in very unexpected ways,

00:12:40.583 --> 00:12:42.963
like this home which caught my attention

00:12:42.963 --> 00:12:46.445
while all the mud and the grass was literally

00:12:46.445 --> 00:12:48.932
seeping out under the front door.

00:12:48.932 --> 00:12:52.731
When I was let in, it appeared that this fifth-floor apartment

00:12:52.731 --> 00:12:56.039
was being transformed into a complete animal farm,

00:12:56.039 --> 00:12:58.930
where six or seven cows stood grazing

00:12:58.930 --> 00:13:03.602
in what otherwise would be the living room.

00:13:03.602 --> 00:13:06.970
But then in the apartment across the hall

00:13:06.970 --> 00:13:09.493
from this cow shed lives a newly married couple

00:13:09.493 --> 00:13:11.319
in what locals describe

00:13:11.319 --> 00:13:19.440
as one of the nicest apartments in the area.

00:13:19.440 --> 00:13:22.666
The attention to this detail astonished me,

00:13:22.666 --> 00:13:25.337
and as the owner of the home so proudly

00:13:25.337 --> 00:13:27.323
led me around this apartment,

00:13:27.323 --> 00:13:31.039
from floor to ceiling, every part was decorated.

00:13:31.039 --> 00:13:34.841
But if it weren't for the strangely familiar

00:13:34.841 --> 00:13:37.704
stomach-churning odor that constantly

00:13:37.704 --> 00:13:41.149
passes through the apartment,

00:13:41.149 --> 00:13:43.742
it would be easy to forget

00:13:43.742 --> 00:13:46.434
that you are standing next to a cow shed

00:13:46.434 --> 00:13:51.931
and on top of a landfill.

00:13:51.931 --> 00:13:54.610
What moved me the most was that despite

00:13:54.610 --> 00:13:56.644
these seemingly inhospitable conditions,

00:13:56.644 --> 00:13:58.437
I was welcomed with open arms

00:13:58.437 --> 00:14:02.363
into a home that was made with love, care,

00:14:02.363 --> 00:14:04.613
and unreserved passion.

00:14:04.613 --> 00:14:07.997
Let's move across the map to China,

00:14:07.997 --> 00:14:11.884
to an area called Shanxi, Henan and Gansu.

00:14:11.884 --> 00:14:15.574
In a region famous for the soft, porous Loess Plateau soil,

00:14:15.574 --> 00:14:18.257
there lived until recently an estimated

00:14:18.257 --> 00:14:22.126
40 million people in these houses underground.

00:14:22.126 --> 00:14:24.577
These dwellings are called the yaodongs.

00:14:24.577 --> 00:14:26.767
Through this architecture by subtraction,

00:14:26.767 --> 00:14:30.354
these yaodongs are built literally inside of the soil.

00:14:30.354 --> 00:14:34.228
In these villages, you see an entirely altered landscape,

00:14:34.228 --> 00:14:36.974
and hidden behind these mounds of dirt

00:14:36.974 --> 00:14:39.474
are these square, rectangular houses

00:14:39.474 --> 00:14:42.065
which sit seven meters below the ground.

00:14:42.065 --> 00:14:44.053
When I asked people why they were digging

00:14:44.053 --> 00:14:45.942
their houses from the ground,

00:14:45.942 --> 00:14:47.965
they simply replied that they are poor wheat

00:14:47.965 --> 00:14:50.145
and apple farmers who didn't have the money

00:14:50.145 --> 00:14:53.546
to buy materials, and this digging out

00:14:53.546 --> 00:14:58.014
was their most logical form of living.

00:14:58.014 --> 00:15:00.912
From Makoko to Zabbaleen, these communities

00:15:00.912 --> 00:15:02.911
have approached the tasks of planning,

00:15:02.911 --> 00:15:05.310
design and management of their communities

00:15:05.310 --> 00:15:07.689
and neighborhoods in ways that respond

00:15:07.689 --> 00:15:11.599
specifically to their environment and circumstances.

00:15:11.599 --> 00:15:13.830
Created by these very people who live,

00:15:13.830 --> 00:15:17.541
work and play in these particular spaces,

00:15:17.541 --> 00:15:20.538
these neighborhoods are intuitively designed

00:15:20.538 --> 00:15:23.576
to make the most of their circumstances.

00:15:23.576 --> 00:15:25.481
In most of these places, the government

00:15:25.481 --> 00:15:28.010
is completely absent, leaving inhabitants

00:15:28.010 --> 00:15:31.929
with no choice but to reappropriate found materials,

00:15:31.929 --> 00:15:34.901
and while these communities are highly disadvantaged,

00:15:34.901 --> 00:15:36.943
they do present examples

00:15:36.943 --> 00:15:39.391
of brilliant forms of ingenuity,

00:15:39.391 --> 00:15:41.719
and prove that indeed we have the ability

00:15:41.719 --> 00:15:45.262
to adapt to all manner of circumstances.

00:15:45.262 --> 00:15:47.455
What makes places like the Torre David

00:15:47.455 --> 00:15:49.252
particularly remarkable

00:15:49.252 --> 00:15:51.153
is this sort of skeleton framework

00:15:51.153 --> 00:15:52.775
where people can have a foundation

00:15:52.775 --> 00:15:54.847
where they can tap into.

00:15:54.847 --> 00:15:57.945
Now imagine what these already ingenious communities

00:15:57.945 --> 00:16:00.037
could create themselves,

00:16:00.037 --> 00:16:02.723
and how highly particular their solutions would be,

00:16:02.723 --> 00:16:05.265
if they were given the basic infrastructures

00:16:05.265 --> 00:16:07.244
that they could tap into.

00:16:07.244 --> 00:16:10.751
Today, you see these large residential development projects

00:16:10.751 --> 00:16:13.206
which offer cookie-cutter housing solutions

00:16:13.206 --> 00:16:15.248
to massive amounts of people.

00:16:15.248 --> 00:16:17.808
From China to Brazil, these projects attempt

00:16:17.808 --> 00:16:20.815
to provide as many houses as possible,

00:16:20.815 --> 00:16:23.018
but they're completely generic

00:16:23.018 --> 00:16:24.923
and simply do not work as an answer

00:16:24.923 --> 00:16:28.252
to the individual needs of the people.

00:16:28.252 --> 00:16:30.706
I would like to end with a quote

00:16:30.706 --> 00:16:33.787
from a friend of mine and a source of inspiration,

00:16:33.787 --> 00:16:36.553
Zita Cobb, the founder of the wonderful

00:16:36.553 --> 00:16:38.229
Shorefast Foundation,

00:16:38.229 --> 00:16:41.318
based out of Fogo Island, Newfoundland.

00:16:41.318 --> 00:16:44.159
She says that "there's this plague of sameness

00:16:44.159 --> 00:16:46.082
which is killing the human joy,"

00:16:46.082 --> 00:16:48.377
and I couldn't agree with her more.

00:16:48.377 --> 00:16:49.820
Thank you.

title: What will a future without secrets look like?
transcript: I would like to tell you a story connecting the notorious privacy incident involving Adam and Eve, and the remarkable shift in the boundaries between public and private which has occurred in the past 10 years.You know the incident. Adam and Eve one day in the Garden of Eden realize they are naked. They freak out. And the rest is history.Nowadays, Adam and Eve would probably act differently.[@Adam Last nite was a blast! loved dat apple LOL][@Eve yep.. babe, know what happened to my pants tho?]We do reveal so much more information about ourselves online than ever before, and so much information about us is being collected by organizations. Now there is much to gain and benefit from this massive analysis of personal information, or big data, but there are also complex tradeoffs that come from giving away our privacy. And my story is about these tradeoffs.We start with an observation which, in my mind, has become clearer and clearer in the past few years, that any personal information can become sensitive information. Back in the year 2000, about 100 billion photos were shot worldwide, but only a minuscule proportion of them were actually uploaded online. In 2010, only on Facebook, in a single month, 2.5 billion photos were uploaded, most of them identified. In the same span of time, computers' ability to recognize people in photos improved by three orders of magnitude. What happens when you combine these technologies together: increasing availability of facial data; improving facial recognizing ability by computers; but also cloud computing, which gives anyone in this theater the kind of computational power which a few years ago was only the domain of three-letter agencies; and ubiquitous computing, which allows my phone, which is not a supercomputer, to connect to the Internet and do there hundreds of thousands of face metrics in a few seconds? Well, we conjecture that the result of this combination of technologies will be a radical change in our very notions of privacy and anonymity.To test that, we did an experiment on Carnegie Mellon University campus. We asked students who were walking by to participate in a study, and we took a shot with a webcam, and we asked them to fill out a survey on a laptop. While they were filling out the survey, we uploaded their shot to a cloud-computing cluster, and we started using a facial recognizer to match that shot to a database of some hundreds of thousands of images which we had downloaded from Facebook profiles. By the time the subject reached the last page on the survey, the page had been dynamically updated with the 10 best matching photos which the recognizer had found, and we asked the subjects to indicate whether he or she found themselves in the photo.Do you see the subject? Well, the computer did, and in fact did so for one out of three subjects.So essentially, we can start from an anonymous face, offline or online, and we can use facial recognition to give a name to that anonymous face thanks to social media data. But a few years back, we did something else. We started from social media data, we combined it statistically with data from U.S. government social security, and we ended up predicting social security numbers, which in the United States are extremely sensitive information.Do you see where I'm going with this? So if you combine the two studies together, then the question becomes, can you start from a face and, using facial recognition, find a name and publicly available information about that name and that person, and from that publicly available information infer non-publicly available information, much more sensitive ones which you link back to the face? And the answer is, yes, we can, and we did. Of course, the accuracy keeps getting worse. [27% of subjects' first 5 SSN digits identified (with 4 attempts)] But in fact, we even decided to develop an iPhone app which uses the phone's internal camera to take a shot of a subject and then upload it to a cloud and then do what I just described to you in real time: looking for a match, finding public information, trying to infer sensitive information, and then sending back to the phone so that it is overlaid on the face of the subject, an example of augmented reality, probably a creepy example of augmented reality. In fact, we didn't develop the app to make it available, just as a proof of concept.In fact, take these technologies and push them to their logical extreme. Imagine a future in which strangers around you will look at you through their Google Glasses or, one day, their contact lenses, and use seven or eight data points about you to infer anything else which may be known about you. What will this future without secrets look like? And should we care?We may like to believe that the future with so much wealth of data would be a future with no more biases, but in fact, having so much information doesn't mean that we will make decisions which are more objective. In another experiment, we presented to our subjects information about a potential job candidate. We included in this information some references to some funny, absolutely legal, but perhaps slightly embarrassing information that the subject had posted online. Now interestingly, among our subjects, some had posted comparable information, and some had not. Which group do you think was more likely to judge harshly our subject? Paradoxically, it was the group who had posted similar information, an example of moral dissonance.Now you may be thinking, this does not apply to me, because I have nothing to hide. But in fact, privacy is not about having something negative to hide. Imagine that you are the H.R. director of a certain organization, and you receive résumés, and you decide to find more information about the candidates. Therefore, you Google their names and in a certain universe, you find this information. Or in a parallel universe, you find this information. Do you think that you would be equally likely to call either candidate for an interview? If you think so, then you are not like the U.S. employers who are, in fact, part of our experiment, meaning we did exactly that. We created Facebook profiles, manipulating traits, then we started sending out résumés to companies in the U.S., and we detected, we monitored, whether they were searching for our candidates, and whether they were acting on the information they found on social media. And they were. Discrimination was happening through social media for equally skilled candidates.Now marketers like us to believe that all information about us will always be used in a manner which is in our favor. But think again. Why should that be always the case? In a movie which came out a few years ago, "Minority Report," a famous scene had Tom Cruise walk in a mall and holographic personalized advertising would appear around him. Now, that movie is set in 2054, about 40 years from now, and as exciting as that technology looks, it already vastly underestimates the amount of information that organizations can gather about you, and how they can use it to influence you in a way that you will not even detect.So as an example, this is another experiment actually we are running, not yet completed. Imagine that an organization has access to your list of Facebook friends, and through some kind of algorithm they can detect the two friends that you like the most. And then they create, in real time, a facial composite of these two friends. Now studies prior to ours have shown that people don't recognize any longer even themselves in facial composites, but they react to those composites in a positive manner. So next time you are looking for a certain product, and there is an ad suggesting you to buy it, it will not be just a standard spokesperson. It will be one of your friends, and you will not even know that this is happening.Now the problem is that the current policy mechanisms we have to protect ourselves from the abuses of personal information are like bringing a knife to a gunfight. One of these mechanisms is transparency, telling people what you are going to do with their data. And in principle, that's a very good thing. It's necessary, but it is not sufficient. Transparency can be misdirected. You can tell people what you are going to do, and then you still nudge them to disclose arbitrary amounts of personal information.So in yet another experiment, this one with students, we asked them to provide information about their campus behavior, including pretty sensitive questions, such as this one. [Have you ever cheated in an exam?] Now to one group of subjects, we told them, "Only other students will see your answers." To another group of subjects, we told them, "Students and faculty will see your answers." Transparency. Notification. And sure enough, this worked, in the sense that the first group of subjects were much more likely to disclose than the second. It makes sense, right? But then we added the misdirection. We repeated the experiment with the same two groups, this time adding a delay between the time we told subjects how we would use their data and the time we actually started answering the questions.How long a delay do you think we had to add in order to nullify the inhibitory effect of knowing that faculty would see your answers? Ten minutes? Five minutes? One minute? How about 15 seconds? Fifteen seconds were sufficient to have the two groups disclose the same amount of information, as if the second group now no longer cares for faculty reading their answers.Now I have to admit that this talk so far may sound exceedingly gloomy, but that is not my point. In fact, I want to share with you the fact that there are alternatives. The way we are doing things now is not the only way they can done, and certainly not the best way they can be done. When someone tells you, "People don't care about privacy," consider whether the game has been designed and rigged so that they cannot care about privacy, and coming to the realization that these manipulations occur is already halfway through the process of being able to protect yourself. When someone tells you that privacy is incompatible with the benefits of big data, consider that in the last 20 years, researchers have created technologies to allow virtually any electronic transactions to take place in a more privacy-preserving manner. We can browse the Internet anonymously. We can send emails that can only be read by the intended recipient, not even the NSA. We can have even privacy-preserving data mining. In other words, we can have the benefits of big data while protecting privacy. Of course, these technologies imply a shifting of cost and revenues between data holders and data subjects, which is why, perhaps, you don't hear more about them.Which brings me back to the Garden of Eden. There is a second privacy interpretation of the story of the Garden of Eden which doesn't have to do with the issue of Adam and Eve feeling naked and feeling ashamed. You can find echoes of this interpretation in John Milton's "Paradise Lost." In the garden, Adam and Eve are materially content. They're happy. They are satisfied. However, they also lack knowledge and self-awareness. The moment they eat the aptly named fruit of knowledge, that's when they discover themselves. They become aware. They achieve autonomy. The price to pay, however, is leaving the garden. So privacy, in a way, is both the means and the price to pay for freedom.Again, marketers tell us that big data and social media are not just a paradise of profit for them, but a Garden of Eden for the rest of us. We get free content. We get to play Angry Birds. We get targeted apps. But in fact, in a few years, organizations will know so much about us, they will be able to infer our desires before we even form them, and perhaps buy products on our behalf before we even know we need them.Now there was one English author who anticipated this kind of future where we would trade away our autonomy and freedom for comfort. Even more so than George Orwell, the author is, of course, Aldous Huxley. In "Brave New World," he imagines a society where technologies that we created originally for freedom end up coercing us. However, in the book, he also offers us a way out of that society, similar to the path that Adam and Eve had to follow to leave the garden. In the words of the Savage, regaining autonomy and freedom is possible, although the price to pay is steep. So I do believe that one of the defining fights of our times will be the fight for the control over personal information, the fight over whether big data will become a force for freedom, rather than a force which will hiddenly manipulate us.Right now, many of us do not even know that the fight is going on, but it is, whether you like it or not. And at the risk of playing the serpent, I will tell you that the tools for the fight are here, the awareness of what is going on, and in your hands, just a few clicks away.Thank you.(Applause)

Now marketers like us to believe

00:07:23.850 --> 00:07:26.119
that all information about us will always

00:07:26.119 --> 00:07:29.392
be used in a manner which is in our favor.

00:07:29.392 --> 00:07:33.107
But think again. Why should that be always the case?

00:07:33.107 --> 00:07:35.771
In a movie which came out a few years ago,

00:07:35.771 --> 00:07:38.324
"Minority Report," a famous scene

00:07:38.324 --> 00:07:40.900
had Tom Cruise walk in a mall

00:07:40.900 --> 00:07:44.676
and holographic personalized advertising

00:07:44.676 --> 00:07:46.511
would appear around him.

00:07:46.511 --> 00:07:49.738
Now, that movie is set in 2054,

00:07:49.738 --> 00:07:51.380
about 40 years from now,

00:07:51.380 --> 00:07:54.288
and as exciting as that technology looks,

00:07:54.288 --> 00:07:56.934
it already vastly underestimates

00:07:56.934 --> 00:07:59.074
the amount of information that organizations

00:07:59.074 --> 00:08:01.557
can gather about you, and how they can use it

00:08:01.557 --> 00:08:04.955
to influence you in a way that you will not even detect.

00:08:04.955 --> 00:08:07.058
So as an example, this is another experiment

00:08:07.058 --> 00:08:09.331
actually we are running, not yet completed.

00:08:09.331 --> 00:08:11.650
Imagine that an organization has access

00:08:11.650 --> 00:08:13.706
to your list of Facebook friends,

00:08:13.706 --> 00:08:15.478
and through some kind of algorithm

00:08:15.478 --> 00:08:19.212
they can detect the two friends that you like the most.

00:08:19.212 --> 00:08:21.492
And then they create, in real time,

00:08:21.492 --> 00:08:24.334
a facial composite of these two friends.

00:08:24.334 --> 00:08:27.403
Now studies prior to ours have shown that people

00:08:27.403 --> 00:08:30.288
don't recognize any longer even themselves

00:08:30.288 --> 00:08:32.750
in facial composites, but they react

00:08:32.750 --> 00:08:34.867
to those composites in a positive manner.

00:08:34.867 --> 00:08:38.282
So next time you are looking for a certain product,

00:08:38.282 --> 00:08:40.841
and there is an ad suggesting you to buy it,

00:08:40.841 --> 00:08:43.748
it will not be just a standard spokesperson.

00:08:43.748 --> 00:08:46.061
It will be one of your friends,

00:08:46.061 --> 00:08:49.364
and you will not even know that this is happening.

00:08:49.364 --> 00:08:51.777
Now the problem is that

00:08:51.777 --> 00:08:54.296
the current policy mechanisms we have

00:08:54.296 --> 00:08:57.734
to protect ourselves from the abuses of personal information

00:08:57.734 --> 00:09:00.718
are like bringing a knife to a gunfight.

00:09:00.718 --> 00:09:03.631
One of these mechanisms is transparency,

00:09:03.631 --> 00:09:06.831
telling people what you are going to do with their data.

00:09:06.831 --> 00:09:08.937
And in principle, that's a very good thing.

00:09:08.937 --> 00:09:12.604
It's necessary, but it is not sufficient.

00:09:12.604 --> 00:09:16.302
Transparency can be misdirected.

00:09:16.302 --> 00:09:18.406
You can tell people what you are going to do,

00:09:18.406 --> 00:09:20.638
and then you still nudge them to disclose

00:09:20.638 --> 00:09:23.261
arbitrary amounts of personal information.

00:09:23.261 --> 00:09:26.147
So in yet another experiment, this one with students,

00:09:26.147 --> 00:09:29.205
we asked them to provide information

00:09:29.205 --> 00:09:31.018
about their campus behavior,

00:09:31.018 --> 00:09:33.958
including pretty sensitive questions, such as this one.

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:34.579
[Have you ever cheated in an exam?]

00:09:34.579 --> 00:09:36.879
Now to one group of subjects, we told them,

00:09:36.879 --> 00:09:39.720
"Only other students will see your answers."

00:09:39.720 --> 00:09:41.299
To another group of subjects, we told them,

00:09:41.299 --> 00:09:44.860
"Students and faculty will see your answers."

00:09:44.860 --> 00:09:47.451
Transparency. Notification. And sure enough, this worked,

00:09:47.451 --> 00:09:48.858
in the sense that the first group of subjects

00:09:48.858 --> 00:09:51.426
were much more likely to disclose than the second.

00:09:51.426 --> 00:09:52.946
It makes sense, right?

00:09:52.946 --> 00:09:54.436
But then we added the misdirection.

00:09:54.436 --> 00:09:57.196
We repeated the experiment with the same two groups,

00:09:57.196 --> 00:09:59.623
this time adding a delay

00:09:59.623 --> 00:10:02.558
between the time we told subjects

00:10:02.558 --> 00:10:04.638
how we would use their data

00:10:04.638 --> 00:10:09.026
and the time we actually started answering the questions.

00:10:09.026 --> 00:10:11.587
How long a delay do you think we had to add

00:10:11.587 --> 00:10:16.200
in order to nullify the inhibitory effect

00:10:16.200 --> 00:10:19.611
of knowing that faculty would see your answers?

00:10:19.611 --> 00:10:21.391
Ten minutes?

00:10:21.391 --> 00:10:23.182
Five minutes?

00:10:23.182 --> 00:10:24.958
One minute?

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:27.007
How about 15 seconds?

00:10:27.007 --> 00:10:29.675
Fifteen seconds were sufficient to have the two groups

00:10:29.675 --> 00:10:31.243
disclose the same amount of information,

00:10:31.243 --> 00:10:33.989
as if the second group now no longer cares

00:10:33.989 --> 00:10:36.645
for faculty reading their answers.

00:10:36.645 --> 00:10:39.981
Now I have to admit that this talk so far

00:10:39.981 --> 00:10:42.461
may sound exceedingly gloomy,

00:10:42.461 --> 00:10:44.182
but that is not my point.

00:10:44.182 --> 00:10:46.881
In fact, I want to share with you the fact that

00:10:46.881 --> 00:10:48.653
there are alternatives.

00:10:48.653 --> 00:10:51.152
The way we are doing things now is not the only way

00:10:51.152 --> 00:10:54.189
they can done, and certainly not the best way

00:10:54.189 --> 00:10:56.216
they can be done.

00:10:56.216 --> 00:11:00.387
When someone tells you, "People don't care about privacy,"

00:11:00.387 --> 00:11:03.029
consider whether the game has been designed

00:11:03.029 --> 00:11:05.753
and rigged so that they cannot care about privacy,

00:11:05.753 --> 00:11:09.015
and coming to the realization that these manipulations occur

00:11:09.015 --> 00:11:10.622
is already halfway through the process

00:11:10.622 --> 00:11:12.880
of being able to protect yourself.

00:11:12.880 --> 00:11:16.590
When someone tells you that privacy is incompatible

00:11:16.590 --> 00:11:18.439
with the benefits of big data,

00:11:18.439 --> 00:11:20.912
consider that in the last 20 years,

00:11:20.912 --> 00:11:22.829
researchers have created technologies

00:11:22.829 --> 00:11:26.147
to allow virtually any electronic transactions

00:11:26.147 --> 00:11:29.896
to take place in a more privacy-preserving manner.

00:11:29.896 --> 00:11:32.451
We can browse the Internet anonymously.

00:11:32.451 --> 00:11:35.129
We can send emails that can only be read

00:11:35.129 --> 00:11:38.838
by the intended recipient, not even the NSA.

00:11:38.838 --> 00:11:41.835
We can have even privacy-preserving data mining.

00:11:41.835 --> 00:11:45.729
In other words, we can have the benefits of big data

00:11:45.729 --> 00:11:47.861
while protecting privacy.

00:11:47.861 --> 00:11:51.652
Of course, these technologies imply a shifting

00:11:51.652 --> 00:11:53.198
of cost and revenues

00:11:53.198 --> 00:11:55.305
between data holders and data subjects,

00:11:55.305 --> 00:11:58.758
which is why, perhaps, you don't hear more about them.

00:11:58.758 --> 00:12:02.464
Which brings me back to the Garden of Eden.

00:12:02.464 --> 00:12:05.244
There is a second privacy interpretation

00:12:05.244 --> 00:12:07.053
of the story of the Garden of Eden

00:12:07.053 --> 00:12:09.149
which doesn't have to do with the issue

00:12:09.149 --> 00:12:11.374
of Adam and Eve feeling naked

00:12:11.374 --> 00:12:13.755
and feeling ashamed.

00:12:13.755 --> 00:12:16.536
You can find echoes of this interpretation

00:12:16.536 --> 00:12:19.318
in John Milton's "Paradise Lost."

00:12:19.318 --> 00:12:23.515
In the garden, Adam and Eve are materially content.

00:12:23.515 --> 00:12:25.619
They're happy. They are satisfied.

00:12:25.619 --> 00:12:27.912
However, they also lack knowledge

00:12:27.912 --> 00:12:29.552
and self-awareness.

00:12:29.552 --> 00:12:32.871
The moment they eat the aptly named

00:12:32.871 --> 00:12:34.164
fruit of knowledge,

00:12:34.164 --> 00:12:36.769
that's when they discover themselves.

00:12:36.769 --> 00:12:40.800
They become aware. They achieve autonomy.

00:12:40.800 --> 00:12:43.926
The price to pay, however, is leaving the garden.

00:12:43.926 --> 00:12:47.807
So privacy, in a way, is both the means

00:12:47.807 --> 00:12:50.769
and the price to pay for freedom.

00:12:50.769 --> 00:12:53.539
Again, marketers tell us

00:12:53.539 --> 00:12:56.558
that big data and social media

00:12:56.558 --> 00:12:59.537
are not just a paradise of profit for them,

00:12:59.537 --> 00:13:01.994
but a Garden of Eden for the rest of us.

00:13:01.994 --> 00:13:03.232
We get free content.

00:13:03.232 --> 00:13:06.355
We get to play Angry Birds. We get targeted apps.

00:13:06.355 --> 00:13:09.252
But in fact, in a few years, organizations

00:13:09.252 --> 00:13:10.861
will know so much about us,

00:13:10.861 --> 00:13:13.571
they will be able to infer our desires

00:13:13.571 --> 00:13:15.775
before we even form them, and perhaps

00:13:15.775 --> 00:13:18.222
buy products on our behalf

00:13:18.222 --> 00:13:20.496
before we even know we need them.

00:13:20.496 --> 00:13:23.733
Now there was one English author

00:13:23.733 --> 00:13:26.778
who anticipated this kind of future

00:13:26.778 --> 00:13:28.183
where we would trade away

00:13:28.183 --> 00:13:31.731
our autonomy and freedom for comfort.

00:13:31.731 --> 00:13:33.892
Even more so than George Orwell,

00:13:33.892 --> 00:13:36.653
the author is, of course, Aldous Huxley.

00:13:36.653 --> 00:13:39.507
In "Brave New World," he imagines a society

00:13:39.507 --> 00:13:41.678
where technologies that we created

00:13:41.678 --> 00:13:43.537
originally for freedom

00:13:43.537 --> 00:13:46.104
end up coercing us.

00:13:46.104 --> 00:13:50.895
However, in the book, he also offers us a way out

00:13:50.895 --> 00:13:54.333
of that society, similar to the path

00:13:54.333 --> 00:13:58.288
that Adam and Eve had to follow to leave the garden.

00:13:58.288 --> 00:14:00.435
In the words of the Savage,

00:14:00.435 --> 00:14:03.504
regaining autonomy and freedom is possible,

00:14:03.504 --> 00:14:06.183
although the price to pay is steep.

00:14:06.183 --> 00:14:11.898
So I do believe that one of the defining fights

00:14:11.898 --> 00:14:14.461
of our times will be the fight

00:14:14.461 --> 00:14:16.848
for the control over personal information,

00:14:16.848 --> 00:14:20.355
the fight over whether big data will become a force

00:14:20.355 --> 00:14:21.644
for freedom,

00:14:21.644 --> 00:14:26.390
rather than a force which will hiddenly manipulate us.

00:14:26.390 --> 00:14:28.983
Right now, many of us

00:14:28.983 --> 00:14:31.736
do not even know that the fight is going on,

00:14:31.736 --> 00:14:34.408
but it is, whether you like it or not.

00:14:34.408 --> 00:14:37.212
And at the risk of playing the serpent,

00:14:37.212 --> 00:14:40.109
I will tell you that the tools for the fight

00:14:40.109 --> 00:14:43.118
are here, the awareness of what is going on,

00:14:43.118 --> 00:14:44.473
and in your hands,

00:14:44.473 --> 00:14:48.213
just a few clicks away.

00:14:48.213 --> 00:14:49.695
Thank you.

00:14:49.695 --> 00:14:54.172
(Applause)

title: Who am I? Think again
transcript: Hetain Patel: (In Chinese)Yuyu Rau: Hi, I'm Hetain. I'm an artist. And this is Yuyu, who is a dancer I have been working with. I have asked her to translate for me.HP: (In Chinese)YR: If I may, I would like to tell you a little bit about myself and my artwork.HP: (In Chinese)YR: I was born and raised near Manchester, in England, but I'm not going to say it in English to you, because I'm trying to avoid any assumptions that might be made from my northern accent.(Laughter)HP: (In Chinese)YR: The only problem with masking it with Chinese Mandarin is I can only speak this paragraph, which I have learned by heart when I was visiting in China. (Laughter) So all I can do is keep repeating it in different tones and hope you won't notice.(Laughter)HP: (In Chinese)(Laughter)YR: Needless to say, I would like to apologize to any Mandarin speakers in the audience.As a child, I would hate being made to wear the Indian kurta pajama, because I didn't think it was very cool. It felt a bit girly to me, like a dress, and it had this baggy trouser part you had to tie really tight to avoid the embarrassment of them falling down. My dad never wore it, so I didn't see why I had to. Also, it makes me feel a bit uncomfortable, that people assume I represent something genuinely Indian when I wear it, because that's not how I feel.HP: (In Chinese)YR: Actually, the only way I feel comfortable wearing it is by pretending they are the robes of a kung fu warrior like Li Mu Bai from that film, "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon."(Music)Okay. So my artwork is about identity and language, challenging common assumptions based on how we look like or where we come from, gender, race, class. What makes us who we are anyway?HP: (In Chinese)YR: I used to read Spider-Man comics, watch kung fu movies, take philosophy lessons from Bruce Lee. He would say things like —HP: Empty your mind. (Laughter) Be formless, shapeless, like water. Now you put water into a cup. It becomes the cup. You put water into a bottle, it becomes the bottle. Put it in a teapot, it becomes the teapot. Now, water can flow or it can crash. Be water, my friend. (Applause)YR: This year, I am 32 years old, the same age Bruce Lee was when he died. I have been wondering recently, if he were alive today, what advice he would give me about making this TED Talk.HP: Don't imitate my voice. It offends me.(Laughter)YR: Good advice, but I still think that we learn who we are by copying others. Who here hasn't imitated their childhood hero in the playground, or mum or father? I have.HP: A few years ago, in order to make this video for my artwork, I shaved off all my hair so that I could grow it back as my father had it when he first emigrated from India to the U.K. in the 1960s. He had a side parting and a neat mustache.At first, it was going very well. I even started to get discounts in Indian shops.(Laughter)But then very quickly, I started to underestimate my mustache growing ability, and it got way too big. It didn't look Indian anymore. Instead, people from across the road, they would shout things like —HP and YR: Arriba! Arriba! Ándale! Ándale!(Laughter)HP: Actually, I don't know why I am even talking like this. My dad doesn't even have an Indian accent anymore. He talks like this now.So it's not just my father that I've imitated. A few years ago I went to China for a few months, and I couldn't speak Chinese, and this frustrated me, so I wrote about this and had it translated into Chinese, and then I learned this by heart, like music, I guess.YR: This phrase is now etched into my mind clearer than the pin number to my bank card, so I can pretend I speak Chinese fluently. When I had learned this phrase, I had an artist over there hear me out to see how accurate it sounded.I spoke the phrase, and then he laughed and told me, "Oh yeah, that's great, only it kind of sounds like a woman."I said, "What?"He said, "Yeah, you learned from a woman?"I said, "Yes. So?"He then explained the tonal differences between male and female voices are very different and distinct, and that I had learned it very well, but in a woman's voice.(Laughter)(Applause)HP: Okay. So this imitation business does come with risk. It doesn't always go as you plan it, even with a talented translator. But I am going to stick with it, because contrary to what we might usually assume, imitating somebody can reveal something unique. So every time I fail to become more like my father, I become more like myself. Every time I fail to become Bruce Lee, I become more authentically me.This is my art. I strive for authenticity, even if it comes in a shape that we might not usually expect. It's only recently that I've started to understand that I didn't learn to sit like this through being Indian. I learned this from Spider-Man.(Laughter)Thank you.(Applause)
